page.title: 09Cauldon Drinking Fountain
page.content: The fountain was given by Charles Bill, whose initials decorate the stonework with the date and "The clouds drop fatness". It was originally provided with drinking cups for travellers and an animal trough. There is an annual village custom of "well" dressing. Wooden boards in the shape of the well are soaked in a pond and are covered with heavily salted clay. A local artist designs the picture which will cover the clay, usually a biblical scene with a quotation. The picture is drawn on to paper which is placed on the clay and the design is pricked through with skewers. The lines are then marked with small pieces of coal and different plants, flowers and petals are positioned like roof tiles so that the rain drains off without damaging the foundations. The finished picture is fitted into the well.
